text: Should I blast out a message in <#CGMJ7323Z|announcements> to let the broader community know about the new channel?

to let the broader community know about the new channel?

text: <@UC2A2ARPT> sounds good. Only reason I can think to hold off is if some of the others in this discussion or in the channel want to put a post in to establish a kind of baseline which will help people see how it’s being used. Though now that I think about it, you could just write that in the announcements channel… I say go for it!

text:
We're opening a new channel: <#C037X8XMFB3|reading-together>

This channel will be host to in-depth discussions of academic papers and other long, substantial, or deep materials that deserve thorough consideration and reflection. It'll also be a place to request these sorts of materials — if you're looking for papers on a specific topic, post a request in this channel and the audience there might be able to help you find some.

Here's how it fits in with our existing channels:

<#C5T9GPWFL|thinking-together> — Deep, substantial discussions emerging from your own thoughts on the future of programming.
<#C037X8XMFB3|reading-together> — Deep, substantial discussions emerging from books or academic papers, and requests for such.
<#CCL5VVBAN|share-your-work> — Links to materials that you created, with the discussion focused on positive critique and encouraging feedback.
<#C5U3SEW6A|linking-together> — Links to materials that you didn't create.
<#C01932BJGE8|present-company> — All other discussions/links that might be of interest to the community.

Why are the channels divided in this way? To help _the audience_ find something interesting to read or discuss. Each channel has a different tenor, a different kind of noise, and when they're mixed together they tend to drown each other out. This plurality of channels places a bit of additional burden on those who post — you need to make sure you're posting to a channel that is compatible with what you're posting. When in doubt, you can DM me to ask where to post something, or just give it your best guess.

It'll also be a place to request these sorts of materials — if you're looking for papers on a specific topic, post a request in this channel and the audience there might be able to help you find some.

Here's how it fits in with our existing channels:
— Deep, substantial discussions emerging from your own thoughts on the future of programming.
— Deep, substantial discussions emerging from books or academic papers, and requests for such.
— Links to materials that you created, with the discussion focused on positive critique and encouraging feedback.
— Links to materials that you didn't create.

— All other discussions/links that might be of interest to the community.

Why are the channels divided in this way? To help

find something interesting to read or discuss. Each channel has a different tenor, a different kind of noise, and when they're mixed together they tend to drown each other out. This plurality of channels places a bit of additional burden on those who post — you need to make sure you're posting to a channel that is compatible with what you're posting. When in doubt, you can DM me to ask where to post something, or just give it your best guess.

text: [Please give me feedback on the above post.]

elements.text: [Please give me feedback on the above post.]

text:
A couple short thoughts on the above. 
• When breaking down all the channels relate, it might be worth clarifying ‘emerging from books’ a little bit more, as you did in the first paragraph. I don't know how to characterise it but a book of ‘startup business strategies’ would like not be a fit, and better placed in <#C5U3SEW6A|linking-together>. I think this is clear in your writing but it could be reinforced. I'm not suggesting a restrictive criteria, just one that's as clear as possible
• IMO you could put “give it your best guess” before “dm me”. I think people do a decent job self-sorting, and having you as a fallback might encourage more posts, instead of people potentially seeing you as a gatekeeper of sorts — even as a perceived uncertainty of social approval of posts, which some may turn into a choice to not engage where they otherwise would have.
